On the contrary [tye]. If the data submitted is 65536 bytes large then no update will occur at all, and a warning will be displayed telling the user such. If the data in wiki is 63000 bytes or larger then it becomes editable by gods only. This means that a user can post a message that exceeds the 63000 barrier. It will be accepted and applied, however the next user that comes along when the page is now say at 64000 bytes will a) if they are a god see a note requesting the wiki is rotated and presenting the usual textbox, or b) if they arent a god see a note saying the wiki cant be updated until its rotated.

So while yes it moves the point requiring action marginally earlier in time it is certainly better than "just makes the problem happen sooner". If the problem happened sooner then we would set the update cutoff below the DB limit, but we arent doing that, we are just removing the textbox that would be used for a submit most likely to be rejected. This means that the user who exceeds the 63000 limit still gets their post applied, but will almost certainly not hit the no-update barrier.

A natural next step would be to make it autorotate the wiki, but I havent had the inclination to go there. Also I really dont like the idea of losing data. It just makes the [gods] life more irritating ad it means non editors lose part of the wiki history for the duration. Compare that against losing the ability to add to the wiki until the matter is escalated to a god and I think the newer approach is a better trade off.

I get that the Site Docs are lagging behind the development, and that it hasn't improved a lot. I'm partially to blame, as I'm one of the hybrids; a member of [SiteDocClan] and [pmdev]. My point about [pmdev] messing up the site docs wasn't even thinkng about a rogue developer sabbotaging the docs. My concern is that if you look at the [SDC Master Plan Wiki] you find that there is some method to the madness of site documentation. It's a lot easier to make site-doc changes than it is to keep such efforts organized and on track. No site documents should be created without someone also taking the time to add them to the master plan table, and there are conventions for keeping track of updates as well.

Concern is that we will lose track of the site docs, if we start creating and updating them without complying with SDC conventions. The Monastery may be better served by making [pmdev] a member group of [SiteDocClan]. It is also in the Monastery's best interest that order be kept. [pmdev] patches have the check-and-balance of a [gods|god] needing to apply them. Patches are recorded in the [Patch Lister], and it's simple to create rollback points. SDC doesn't enjoy such tools, and relies on compliance with various conventions to maintain order. These conventions include both methods of documenting changes, additions, and updates, as well as adherence to style points as described in the [SDC Master Plan Wiki].

It is probably a good idea for [pmdev] to have its own policy of individual members ensuring that the site documents reflect any changes they've made to site code. Seeing a patch through to the end means seeing it get documented as well. To this end, it makes sense that [pmdev] become a part of [SiteDocClan]. We just need to exercise care that we remain vigilant on maintaining order in what gets done.

My thinking goes like this:

  • [pmdev] should should be placed inside [SiteDocClan] so that all [pmdev]ers are capable of modifing documentation to reflect how the code actually works.   • [SiteDocClan] should be in the position to take the lead with regard to enhancing documentation. I believe that is an important motivational aspect. I think that if an SDC'er creates an updated documentation for a code node of some sort (primarily this would be [SuperDoc]s at this point), then a [pmdev]er is much more likely to make the code change to use that documentation. (And to make it work according to the requirements of the code, such as adding the appropriate tags/sections to the pmdev'er contribution.)
  • [PMDev] must also be able to initiate such an action, but i see this happening more with new patches and rollouts than retrofits.   • I think that for most viewable code nodes there should be a corresponding [sitedoclet]. As i proposed below the sitedoclet should be named the same as the code node but for a "sitedoclet" appended to the name. Then handle_scratch_pad_viewer would do a htmlcode('get_sitedoclet','Scratch Pad Viewer Sitedoclet', ...) etc. Maybe [get_sitedoclet] should be modified to automatically add the "sitedoclet" to the name...

Hi folks. I've released a new feature designed to help the [SiteDocClan] guys help the [pmdev] folks document their stuff. This would be a new nodetype called [sitedoclet]. These are similar to [sitefaqlet]'s except that they are designed and intended to be used by [htmlcode] and other code based [nodetype]s.

The only node so far using this stuff is [Voting/Experience System], with the documentation being placed in [Voting/Experience System sitedoclet]. SDC have the appropriate rights to edit and modify these nodes.

The [sitedoclet]s are accessed by [pmdev]ers via the [get_sitedoclet] node, which allows a number of special techniques to all the two groups to work together. These are via what I call "fields" or "sections", and via substitution "tags" in the sitedoclet. Sections start like this: (there is no end tag, multiple sections can be included in a single doctext, conversly a [sitedoclet] need not have any sections at all. Its all up to the [pmdev]er who does the work.) Tags look like this: these special tags are designated by the [pmdev]er who writes the code. [get_sitedoclet] will handle substituting in the appropriate content for the tags, and returning to the [pmdev]er the correct section. So its wise not to delete, or change these tags. However the rest of the content is available for editing. In the example I have prepared I've only used tags, but other [pmdev]ers might prefer to use sections.

In essence sections allow the pmdever to position the documentation, and tags allow SDC to position whatever it is that the [pmdev]er thinks is needed. So for instance in the example node there are the and tags. Both of these values will be provided by the code, and its up to SDC where to put them. As i said, if the developer chooses, they can take the opposite tack and ask SDC to manage sections, and then the [pmdev]er will place them in their output as is needed.

At the current point we are lacking in various nice-to-haves to make this process easier. As such my approach is that the [sitedoclet] associated with a node will have the same title, except with 'sitedoclet' appended to it. This means that if you hit a code node of some sort that you think should be available to you, then just change the name as appropriate. If the node does in fact use a [sitedoctlet] then it should take you there. We can figure out a more intelligent way to manage stuff like this as we go along, and ideas present themselves.

Obviously however there will be alot of stuff that doesnt use this, as such I think the best approach is that when folks notice them inform [pmdev] via the [id://322009] and likewise pmdev will either inform people here as well as we start releasing new sitedoclets.

Anyway, hopefully this is a good step towards opening up all the harder to document and manage nodes for the future. Cheers.
